title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #275: Covering Congruences**

If r congruences cover 2^r consecutive integers, they cover all integers.

**Status:** SOLVED (1970)

**Solvers:** Selfridge (independently), Crittenden-Vanden Eynden

The bound 2^r is tight.
mathContext: Covering systems are fundamental in combinatorial number theory.

title: Congruence Class
content:
**CongruenceClass(a, n):**

The set {x ∈ ℤ : x ≡ a (mod n)} of all integers congruent to a modulo n.

This is the arithmetic progression a, a±n, a±2n, ...

title: Covering System
content:
**CoveringSystem:**

A structure containing:
- size: number of congruence classes
- residues: the aᵢ values
- moduli: the nᵢ values (positive)

Represents {aᵢ (mod nᵢ) : 1 ≤ i ≤ r}.

title: Is Covered
content:
**IsCovered(C, x):**

Integer x is covered by system C if x belongs to at least one of the congruence classes in C.

title: Covers All
content:
**CoversAll(C):**

The system C is a complete covering system - every integer is covered.

This is the goal: when does finite data imply infinite coverage?

title: Consecutive Integers
content:
**ConsecutiveIntegers(a, n):**

The set {a, a+1, ..., a+n-1} of n consecutive integers starting at a.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**erdos_275_theorem:**

If r congruence classes cover 2^r consecutive integers, they cover all integers.

**This is the central result of Problem #275!**

title: Crittenden-Vanden Eynden
content:
**crittenden_vanden_eynden:**

Alternative formulation: r arithmetic progressions covering {0, ..., 2^r-1} cover all integers.

Published in Proc. AMS (1970).

title: Optimal Example
content:
**OptimalExample(r):**

The system {2^(i-1) (mod 2^i) : 1 ≤ i ≤ r}.

Covers x iff x has a 1 in some bit position 1 through r.

Misses exactly the multiples of 2^r (all first r bits are 0).

title: Optimal Example Coverage
content:
**optimal_example_coverage:**

x is covered by OptimalExample(r) ⟺ 2^r ∤ x

Covers everything except multiples of 2^r.

title: Tightness
content:
**not_covered_2r_minus_1:**

There exists a system of r classes covering 2^r - 1 consecutive integers but NOT all integers.

Shows the bound 2^r is exactly tight.

title: Pigeonhole Intuition
content:
**pigeonhole_intuition:**

With r classes and 2^r integers, binary representation ensures every pattern of 'hits' is represented.

If covering holds for all patterns, it extends to all ℤ.

title: Period Argument
content:
**period_argument:**

Congruence classes are periodic. The remarkable fact is that 2^r consecutive integers suffice regardless of the specific moduli nᵢ.

title: Binary Connection
content:
**binary_connection:**

2^r consecutive integers represent all r-bit patterns.

Any integer shares its low r bits with some element of {0, ..., 2^r-1}.

title: Proof Method
content:
**crittenden_vanden_eynden_proof:**

The proof uses induction on the structure of moduli mod 2:
1. Consider classes with even vs odd moduli
2. Track coverage through parity analysis
3. Base case and inductive step use binary structure

title: Is Covering System
content:
**IsCoveringSystem(C):**

C is a covering system iff CoversAll(C).

The study of such systems was pioneered by Erdős.

title: Minimum Odd Modulus Problem
content:
**minimum_odd_modulus_problem:**

Does there exist a covering system with all distinct odd moduli?

**Erdős offered $1000 for this problem!**

Status: Still OPEN.

title: Exactly Covering
content:
**IsExactlyCovering(C, k):**

Every integer is covered exactly k times.

For k=1, these are 'disjoint covering systems' - partitions of ℤ by congruence classes.

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_275:**

Combines both parts:
1. Main theorem: 2^r consecutive ⟹ all integers
2. Tightness: 2^r - 1 consecutive ⟹ NOT all integers

**Status:** SOLVED (1970)

title: Historical Timeline
content:
**historical_timeline:**

- 1965: Erdős poses the problem
- 1970: Selfridge solves (unpublished)
- 1970: Crittenden-Vanden Eynden publish in Proc. AMS

title: Open Problem
content:
**open_problem:**

Erdős's $1000 problem: covering system with all distinct odd moduli?

Remains one of the famous open problems in number theory.
